SENT.plain: To investigate the relationship between the fetal hemoglobin-containing erythroblasts (F blasts) and apoptosis in myelodysplastic syndromes (MDS), we immunohistochemically assessed F blasts, F cells, and apoptosis in 137 patients with MDS
A marked increase in the number of F blasts in the bone marrow was identified in 116 of 137 patients (84.7%), and the number of F cells was elevated in 54 patients (39.4%)

Among the erythroblasts stained by anti-glycophorin C antibody, the mean percentage of F blasts was 14.63 +/- 9.17% in MDS, which was significantly higher than that in non-MDS patients with stress erythropoiesis (4.82 +/- 3.35%, P < 0.01), although there were no significant differences in the number of F cells between these groups
In particular, 62 of the 137 MDS patients (45.3%) had an apparent increase in F blasts but no elevation of F cells
The apoptotic rate was significantly higher in the patients with a F blast/F cell (Fb/Fc) ratio >or=5.0 than in those with a Fb/Fc ratio <1.0 (P < 0.01)
The results indicate that F cell precursors are incapable of maturing into functioning end-stage F cells, presumably owing to apoptotic cell death
The measurement of F blasts in the bone marrow is needed for the precise evaluation of fetal-type erythropoiesis in MDS
